message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Signaling Theory: State of the Theory and Its Future
Paper Abstract: Signaling theory is about decision-making and communication. It describes scenarios where signalers send observable signals that carry credible information about unobservable qualities. When decision-makers have incomplete or imperfect information, signals can help them make better decisions. The power of a signal, though, lies in its cost, with the best signals being highly costly for low-quality signalers and less costly for high-quality signalers. Given the centrality of these ideas in the organizational sciences, we examine management studies that use signaling theory to help explain phenomena that occur within and among organizations. Our review draws attention to how signaling theorists have introduced important complexities to the signaling process, uncovered theoretical boundary conditions of signaling, described new actors within signaling systems, and demonstrated novel ways to apply signaling theory to understand behavior in an array of research contexts involving a wide range of organizational stakeholders. We also offer ideas about how scholars can account for costs when they apply the theory, extend the theory in more organizational settings, and create abstract extensions of the theory’s major concepts. Our intent is to provide researchers with a panoramic perspective on the state of signaling theory and inspire further development so that we can collectively advance signaling theory as much in the next decade as it has advanced in the last.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the web search results for "Communication":

## Overview of Communication

Communication is commonly defined as the transmission of information. However, its precise definition is disputed and there are disagreements about whether unintentional or failed transmissions are included and whether communication not only transmits meaning but also creates it.

## Types of Communication

Communication takes many forms:

- **Verbal Communication**: Verbal communication involves the exchange of messages in linguistic form, including spoken and written messages as well as sign language.

- **Non-Verbal Communication**: Non-verbal communication happens without the use of a linguistic system, for example, using body language, touch, and facial expressions.

- **Interpersonal vs. Intrapersonal**: Another distinction is between interpersonal communication, which happens between distinct persons, and intrapersonal communication, which is communication with oneself.

## Communicative Competence

Communicative competence is the ability to communicate well and applies to the skills of formulating messages and understanding them.

## Non-Human Communication

Communication extends beyond humans. Non-human forms of communication include animal and plant communication.(no content)Animal communication is used in areas like courtship and mating, parent–offspring relations, navigation, and self-defense.

## Historical Development

Human communication has a long history and how people exchange information has evolved over time. These changes were usually triggered by the development of new communication technologies.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Information asymmetry"

Links: [{"title":"Information asymmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_asymmetry"},{"title":"The Market for Lemons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Market_for_Lemons"},{"title":"Agency cost - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agency_cost"},{"title":"Law School Transparency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_School_Transparency"},{"title":"Category:Asymmetric information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Asymmetric_information"},{"title":"Economic transparency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_transparency"},{"title":"Suelette Dreyfus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suelette_Dreyfus"},{"title":"Sharp power - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharp_power"},{"title":"California Privacy Rights Act - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Privacy_Rights_Act"},{"title":"Z-channel (information theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z-channel_(information_theory)"}]

## Information Asymmetry

Information asymmetry is a situation where one party has more or better information than the other in contract theory, mechanism design, and economics.

### Effects and Problems

Information asymmetry creates an imbalance of power in transactions, which can sometimes cause the transactions to be inefficient, causing market failure in the worst case.(no content)Examples of this problem are adverse selection, moral hazard, and monopolies of knowledge.

### Classic Example: The Market for Lemons

When a used car is sold, the seller is likely to have a much better understanding of the car's condition and hence its market value than the buyer, who can only estimate the market value based on the information provided by the seller.(no content)Adverse selection is a phenomenon where sellers are not willing to sell high quality goods at the lower prices buyers are willing to pay, with the result that buyers get lower quality goods.

### Types of Problems

Two main types of problems resulting from asymmetries are adverse selection and moral hazard problems. The distinction between those two is based on timing: adverse selection regards behavior before a contract takes place whereas moral hazard describes a party's action after the contract had already been made.

### Nobel Prize Recognition

The 2001 Nobel Prize in Economics was awarded to George Akerlof, Michael Spence, and Joseph E. Stiglitz for their "analyses of markets with asymmetric information".

Web search results for query: "Signaling theory"

Links: [{"title":"Costly signaling theory in evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Costly_signaling_theory_in_evolutionary_psychology"},{"title":"Signalling theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signalling_theory"},{"title":"Signalling (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signalling_(economics)"},{"title":"Talk:Signalling theory/GA1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Signalling_theory%2FGA1?oldformat=true"},{"title":"Signaling game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signaling_game"},{"title":"Lewis signaling game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lewis_signaling_game"},{"title":"Handicap principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handicap_principle"},{"title":"Amotz Zahavi - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amotz_Zahavi"},{"title":"Friendship jealousy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friendship_jealousy"},{"title":"Dividend policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Dividend_Decision"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about signaling theory:

## Overview

Signaling theory is a body of theoretical work examining communication between individuals, both within species and across species. The concept has multiple applications across different fields.

## Evolutionary Biology

The central question is how organisms with conflicting interests, such as in sexual selection, are expected to provide honest signals rather than deceive or cheat.(no content)Signals evolve because they modify the behaviour of the receiver to benefit the signaller.(no content)Signals may be honest, conveying information which usefully increases the fitness of the receiver, or dishonest.

A key concept is the **handicap principle**, which asserts that secondary sexual characteristics are costly signals, which are reliable indicators of the signaller's quality, since they cost the signaller resources that lower-quality individuals could not afford.

## Economics

In contract theory, signaling is the idea that one party (the agent) credibly conveys some information about itself to another party (the principal).(no content)Signaling theory was more fully developed by Michael Spence, specifically in the context of observed knowledge gaps between organisations and prospective employees.(no content)In Spence's job-market signaling model, (potential) employees send a signal about their ability level to the employer by acquiring education credentials.

## Game Theory

In game theory, a signaling game is a type of a dynamic Bayesian game where one player takes action, the signal, to convey information to another player.

Links: [{"title":"Costly signaling theory in evolutionary psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Costly_signaling_theory_in_evolutionary_psychology"},{"title":"Signalling theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signalling_theory"},{"title":"Signalling (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signalling_(economics)"},{"title":"Talk:Signalling theory/GA1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Signalling_theory%2FGA1?oldformat=true"},{"title":"Signaling game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signaling_game"},{"title":"Lewis signaling game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lewis_signaling_game"},{"title":"Handicap principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handicap_principle"},{"title":"Amotz Zahavi - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amotz_Zahavi"},{"title":"Friendship jealousy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friendship_jealousy"},{"title":"Dividend policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Dividend_Decision"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about signaling theory:

## Overview

Signaling theory is a body of theoretical work examining communication between individuals, both within species and across species. The concept has multiple applications across different fields.

## Evolutionary Biology

The central question is how organisms with conflicting interests, such as in sexual selection, are expected to provide honest signals rather than deceive or cheat.(no content)Signals evolve because they modify the behaviour of the receiver to benefit the signaller.(no content)Signals may be honest, conveying information which usefully increases the fitness of the receiver, or dishonest.

A key concept is the **handicap principle**, which asserts that secondary sexual characteristics are costly signals, which are reliable indicators of the signaller's quality, since they cost the signaller resources that lower-quality individuals could not afford.

## Economics

In contract theory, signaling is the idea that one party (the agent) credibly conveys some information about itself to another party (the principal).(no content)Signaling theory was more fully developed by Michael Spence, specifically in the context of observed knowledge gaps between organisations and prospective employees.(no content)In Spence's job-market signaling model, (potential) employees send a signal about their ability level to the employer by acquiring education credentials.

## Game Theory

In game theory, a signaling game is a type of a dynamic Bayesian game where one player takes action, the signal, to convey information to another player.

Web search results for query: "Decision-making"

Links: [{"title":"Decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making"},{"title":"Consensus decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making"},{"title":"Decision fatigue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_fatigue"},{"title":"Decision-making under deep uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making_under_deep_uncertainty"},{"title":"Military Decision Making Process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_Decision_Making_Process"},{"title":"Memory and decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_and_decision-making"},{"title":"Models of judicial decision making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Models_of_judicial_decision_making"},{"title":"Data-informed decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data-informed_decision-making"},{"title":"Judgment and Decision Making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judgment_and_Decision_Making"},{"title":"Optimal decision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_decision"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of decision-making:

## Definition and Core Concept

In psychology, decision-making is regarded as the cognitive process resulting in the selection of a belief or a course of action among several possible alternative options.(no content)It could be either rational or irrational.

## Key Aspects of Decision-Making

**Analysis Process**: A major part of decision-making involves the analysis of a finite set of alternatives described in terms of evaluative criteria.

**Expert vs. Intuitive Decision-Making**: In situations with higher time pressure, higher stakes, or increased ambiguities, experts may use intuitive decision-making rather than structured approaches and may follow a recognition-primed decision that fits their experience.

**Environmental Factors**: The decision-maker's environment can play a part in the decision-making process, as environmental complexity is a factor that influences cognitive function.

## Related Challenges

**Decision Fatigue**: Decision fatigue is the tendency for peoples' decision making to become impaired as a result of having recently taken multiple decisions.

**Analysis Paralysis**: Analysis paralysis is the state that a person enters where they are unable to make a decision, in effect paralyzing the outcome.

## Modern Approaches

Decision making under deep uncertainty (DMDU) is a decision science practice and analytical framework that evaluates potential solutions across multiple plausible future scenarios rather than attempting to predict a single future outcome.

Web search results for query: "Organizational behavior"

Links: [{"title":"Organizational behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_behavior"},{"title":"Organizational behavior and human resources - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_behavior_and_human_resources"},{"title":"Annual Review of Organizational Psychology and Organizational Behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Organizational_Psychology_and_Organizational_Behavior"},{"title":"Positive organizational behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive_organizational_behavior"},{"title":"Organizational behavior management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_behavior_management"},{"title":"Research in Organizational Behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_in_Organizational_Behavior"},{"title":"Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_Behavior_and_Human_Decision_Processes"},{"title":"Journal of Organizational Behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Organizational_Behavior"},{"title":"Organizational citizenship behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_citizenship_behavior"},{"title":"Category:Organizational behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Organizational_behavior"}]

Here are the search results for "Organizational Behavior":

## Definition and Overview

Organizational behavior is the "study of human behavior in organizational settings, the interface between human behavior and the organization, and the organization itself". It studies human behavior in social settings with an emphasis on explaining, predicting, and understanding behavior in organizations.

## Key Focus Areas

Organizational behavior examines topics such as motivation, leadership behavior, task performance, problem solving and decision making, group functioning, and other classes of behavior relevant to organizational effectiveness. One of the main goals of organizational behavior research is "to revitalize organizational theory and develop a better conceptualization of organizational life".

## Research Methods

A variety of methods are used in organizational behavior, many of which are found in other social sciences. Quantitative research allows organizational behavior to be studied/compared through numerical data, with key advantages including efficient examinations of large groups at lower costs and in less time.

## Historical Development

The best known theories today originate from Henri Fayol, Chester Barnard, and Mary Parker Follet, who each drew from their experience to develop models of effective organizational management with a shared focus on human behavior and motivation.

## Related Subtopics

Several related fields and concepts fall under organizational behavior, including organizational behavior management (OBM), a subdiscipline of applied behavior analysis which applies behavior analytic principles and contingency management techniques to change behavior in organizational settings, and organizational citizenship behavior (OCB), a person's voluntary commitment within an organization or company that is not part of his or her contractual tasks.
